Compiling for Host Systems

The exact mechanism for compiling a program using SPMIDI will vary from platform to platform. But if you follow these steps then you should be able to compile an example program on your system.

In order to play MIDI files, we need access to an audio device. We use the PortAudio software library, a cross-platform audio API with support for Windows, Mac OS 9 and X, Linux, Solaris, and SGI.

Compiling Mobileer for Windows

In order to compile a working ME*000 program, you should:
  1. Add all of the files in the "spmidi/engine" folder to your project or Makefile.
  2. If you want to use PortAudio for audio output on Windows then add the file "spmidi/lib/PortAudioWMME.lib" to your project. If you want more information about PortAudio for other platforms then visit here.
  3. Add some utility files such as:
    "spmidi/util/spmidi_errortext.c" so you can call SPMUtil_GetErrorText(errcode)
    "spmidi/util/spmidi_load.c" so you can call SPMUtil_LoadFileImage(filename)
  4. Add an example file for ME1000, for example "spmidi/examples/play_scale.c".

Folders to Search for Header Files

Specify the following folders as the place to look for header files. For "gcc"  use the -I command line option, for example: -Ispmidi/util
  1. "spmidi/engine"
  2. "spmidi/includes"
  3. "spmidi/util"

To use the standard release for ME2000, also add the export folder to the include path. If you have a custom export directory then use that folder instead.

"spmidi/export"
